questions.q: Should you walk or run in the rain?
questions.a: You should run in the rain. Running minimizes the time you spend in the rain, which reduces your total wetness.

questions.q: What is the formula for total wetness?
questions.a: Total wetness equals (wetness per second times time spent in rain) plus (wetness per meter times meters travelled).

questions.q: When will you stay the driest?
questions.a: When standing still.

questions.q: Why does time matter more than speed?
questions.a: Because the rain hitting you from above is constant per unit of time. The less time you spend in the rain, the less water hits you from above.

questions.q: What analogy is used to explain the side rain?
questions.a: A snowplough analogy.

questions.q: Does the volume of a parallelepiped depend on its slant?
questions.a: No, the volume of a parallelepiped does not depend on its slant.

questions.q: What happens when you move out of the way of one raindrop?
questions.a: You move into the way of another raindrop.

questions.q: What happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object?
questions.a: According to relativity and physics, they are actually the same thing viewed from different reference frames, and they would pass through each other without interaction.

questions.q: What is the principle of relativity?
questions.a: Because of relativity. There is no preferred frame of reference - if you move relative to an object, from your perspective the object is moving. Movement depends on the observer's perspective.

questions.q: What is Newton's second law mentioned in the video?
questions.a: Force equals mass times acceleration F=MA. An object's acceleration equals the total force divided by its mass.

questions.q: How much mass does an un-acceleratable object have?
questions.a: An un-acceleratable object would have infinite mass.

questions.q: Are unstoppable forces and immovable objects the same?
questions.a: Yes, they are the same thing viewed from different reference frames. Both are objects that cannot be accelerated.

questions.q: What does relativity clearly tell us about immovable objects?
questions.a: The principle of relativity tells us there is no such thing as an immovable object.

questions.q: Why is pink not a real color?
questions.a: Pink or magenta doesn't exist in the visible light spectrum. It's a mix of red and blue light.

questions.q: What colors are in the visible spectrum?
questions.a: The visible spectrum contains red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet.

questions.q: If you roll up the color where, what is between red and violet?
questions.a: A gap.

questions.q: Why should pink be called minus-green?
questions.a: Because pink is what happens when you take white light and take out the green.

questions.q: What should pink be called?
questions.a: Pink should be called minus-green.

questions.q: How many blades do the vast majority of modern windmills have?
questions.a: The vast majority of modern windmills have three blades.

questions.q: Where does the first reason come from?
questions.a: The first reason comes from physics.

questions.q: What does adding more blades to a windmill do?
questions.a: Adding more blades allows the windmill to generate more torque, but also increases drag.

questions.q: What speeds do many bladed windmills work better at?
questions.a: Many bladed windmills work better at lower rotational speeds.

questions.q: What speeds do fewer bladed windmills work better at?
questions.a: Fewer bladed windmills work better at higher rotational speeds.

questions.q: What does having an odd number of blades do for windmills?
questions.a: Wind loads are more evenly distributed across the face of the rotor, bending forces are reduced as a result.

questions.q: Why Do Wind Turbines Have Three Blades?
questions.a: Physics says that three blade rotors are most efficient, engineering says that for the same cost, three blades are less likely to brake than 2 blades, and human comfort says are not noisy.
